**0. Technical Summary**

 

**1. Introduction:**

**1.1 Introduction**

This paper is seeking to understand the impact the Energy Price Guarantee and Energy Bill Support Scheme impact on consumers during the energy price crisis from October 2022 to January 2024. These policies were introduced to support consumers during this period to reduce negative externalities associated with reductions in energy consumption associated with higher energy prices. We will seek to understand their impact for typical consumers and assess whether these policy options led to the most efficient micro-economic outcomes under the circumstances. This paper will also observe whether alternative subsidy types would have been more effective at improving consumer welfare.  

 

**1.2 Background to the policies**

 

From the period of August 2021 to January 2024, UK wholesale energy prices saw a period of sustained volatility and elevation, influenced by supply side concerns around the bounce back from Covid and the Russia-Ukraine war. Figure 11 indicates how wholesale gas prices increased exponentially during this period, peaking August 2023, a similar trend was observed for electricity. The wholesale peaks fed through to significant increases consumer energy prices; in the run up to the policies being announced, the default tariff cap (the energy price cap), the upper price for consumer energy which is set by Ofgem quarterly, rose by 54% in April 2022 and by a further 80% in October 2022. As a result of these price increased, and growing concern about further increases in energy prices the UK Government introduced measures to support and reduce the cost of energy to the average household2. These policies were introduced to negate negative externalities associated with the expected price increases and subsequent reductions in energy use, notably health impacts3. 

![A graph of the price of energy

Description automatically generated](data:image/png;base64,){alt="A graph of the price of energy

Description automatically generated"} 

Figure 1: Wholesale gas price over time 

The measures were introduced in the form of the Energy Price Guarantee (EPG) and the Energy Bills Support Scheme (EBSS), both intended to reduce the cost of a typical household energy bill and for which all GB households were eligible. The EPG was introduced as a cap on the unit rate of energy paid by consumers, making consumption per kilowatt-hour subsidised at point of use, with the difference between the actual consumer cost and the set unit rate paid by the Treasury4. This can be seen in figure 2 below, where the black line represents the energy price guarantee and the shaded area indicate the effective subsidy when the EPG was set at £2,500, figure 2 also indicates the price during the period for which both EBSS and EPG were operational Oct 2022 to March 2023. The EBSS was introduced to provide credit directly to consumers. Instead of being a subsidy at point of use, it was a subsidy paid into consumer energy balances, increasing positive credit balances, and reducing negative balances.  

![](data:image/png;base64,) 

Figure 2: EPG effective subsidy 

For the EPG the rate of subsidy changed as the price cap value changed per quarter and the EPG increased in July 2023 to £3,000. The highest unit subsidy was seen Jan 23 to April 23, where the unit rate set by the EPG was 32.42p/KWh for electricity and 9.84p/KWh gas, this compared to the expected price without subsidy seen in the price cap of 67.47p/KWh for electricity and 17.08p/KWh gas. This was therefore providing an effective 35.05p/KWh subsidy for electricity and for gas 7.24p/KWh. These provided substantial savings for consumers during this quarter. The EBSS saw a consistent £67 paid into accounts at monthly intervals for the period 6 months.  

It is likely that consumer awareness of these two policies vary, the EPG being an effective point of use subsidy may have been less noticeable to consumers than the EBSS which was paid into credit balances and will have been noted on their credit statements, Ofgem survey data suggests this is true, with more people (of those aware of the measures) thinking they were eligible for EBSS than EPG, despite all households with an electricity connection being eligible for both5.  

**The implementation of these policies will have had different impacts on the welfare of recipients. The EPG being a unit rate subsidy will have likely been slightly regressive in nature, as it provided a higher subsidy for those will more usage those with higher energy bills will have received more direct support. Conversely the EBSS would have been slightly more progressive in nature, providing relatively more support to those consumers on lower energy consumption and subsequently may have led to more progressive welfare outcomes.**

**While the EPG improved consumer welfare and negated negative externalities associated the lack of policy intervention, it is possible there could have been a more targeted approach by which social outcomes were improved. The most notable negative externality associated with high electricity prices are excessive winter death which are highly associated with older age6, these older groups are typically also on the lowest incomes on with those 65+ seeing 28% lower disposable household incomes when compared with ages 25-647.**

 

 

**2. Micro-economic Theory**

**2.1 Definitions**

In this section, we will consider consumer behaviour to energy by setting out a simplified microeconomic framework to examine how price elasticity, consumer surplus and utility maximisation change under different scenarios. 

 

Prior to this we must set out some definitions that we will use in this report: 

-   Consumer: In this report, a consumer is defined as a “household” which consumes a number of Megawatt hours (MWh) of an energy commodity. They are not strictly one individual and we do not make any distinctions of households of more than one person. We only consider consumption for energy charged in energy bills.

-   Payment method: Consumers are assumed to pay bills by direct debit only, as such they are in scope for the standard EBSS and EPG schemes (alternative policies were put in place for consumers who pay via a different method e.g., pre-payment meters). The English Housing Survey 2021-22 cites that most consumers use direct debits for payments at 81% for electricity and 82% for gas respectively (DHLUC, 2023). 

 

As a theoretical study, we have not investigated whether the definitions above exclude important consumer groups (for example, if non-natural gas users are correlated with lower income groups). However, we feel that for the purposes of the report the definitions cover a representative view of all UK consumers. 

 

**2.2 Elasticity**

Elasticity is a concept that measures how sensitive one variable is to another, detonated

. For this report, the price elasticity we refer to is the “price elasticity of demand” which is the percentage change in the quantity demanded of a good due to a small percentage change in its price, denoted as

𝜀𝑥𝑖𝑝𝑖𝜀����

(QMUL, 2023b), and will be referred to simply as price elasticity.  

In this report we comment on the relative elasticity of a good as by definition (Khan Academy, 2024).

A variety of factors influence the price elasticity of a good (Bijmolt, van Heerde and Pieters, 2005). In the context of energy as a good we posit that some of the most important factors are whether a consumer considers the good essential, whether there are any substitutes for the good and whether consumers are constrained in their ability to adjust their consumption in the short-term or long-term. The final factor leads to defining two separate price elasticities in the literature, namely the short-term price elasticity and the long-term price elasticity.   

 

A recent meta-analysis on the literature estimated a price elasticity of energy demand in the short term of −0.21, and −0.61 in the long term across a range of sectors, energy sources, countries between 1990 and 2016 (Labandeira, Labeaga and López-Otero, 2017). The paper breaks this down into the components of energy, with Electricity having a short-term value of -0.126 and a long term value of -0.365 (both values at the 10% significance level) and Natural Gas having a short term value of -0.180 and a long term value of -0.684 (at the 1% significance level).  

 

These values indicate that energy, in aggregate, is an inelastic good; meaning that demand for energy is relatively insensitive to significant price changes. As expected, the short-term price elasticity is relatively more inelastic compared to the long-term price elasticity, showing that consumers can make longer-term adjustments to change their demand (e.g., better insulation of the home). As an inelastic good, we would expect policies that affect the price of energy, all things being equal, to have a less proportional impact on demand. 

 

There are limited other goods that consumers can switch to, as indicated by the almost 100% use of electricity and 78% use of natural gas by consumers. This further decreases the price elasticity of energy. 

 

Consumers use energy for a variety of needs, we can categorise these as: 

-   Essential needs: Cooking, Heating (to tolerable levels), Lighting 

-   Discretionary needs: Appliances, Recreation, Lifestyle changes 

Intuitively, we can realise that there is a different price elasticity of demand for each of these needs with non-discretionary uses being price insensitive and the opposite true for discretionary use (Van Raaij and Verhallen, 1983). Therefore, an individual consumer’s price elasticity of demand is a function of their behaviour.

The literature is sparse on specifically how the price elasticity changes for different income levels for UK consumers but does examine the relationship for other consumer groups.  

 

Nesbakken (1999) examined the price sensitivity of residential energy consumption in Norway using cross-sectional annual data from Norwegian expenditure surveys for 3-years from 1993-1995 for a low-income group (defined as average or below average income), a high-come group (defined as above average income) and all consumers (Nesbakken, 1999).  

 

Bakaloglou & Charlier (2019) examined the same relationship for French consumers using cross-sectional annual data from a survey conducted by a French Ministry sub-division for a low-income group (3 lowest deciles of income), a high-income group (3-highest deciles of income) and all consumers (Bakaloglou and Charlier, 2019).  

 

Their findings are summarised in Table 1 below:

The above results indicate that lower-income consumers face a more inelastic demand, thus are less sensitive to price changes, and supports the short-term price elasticity being lower than the long-term price elasticity.  

 

This result may seem counter-intuitive, given that the expenditure on energy for higher-income consumers is relatively low, you may suppose that they would be more price insensitive. There are a few possible explanations for this. Firstly, low-income groups will need to spend a proportionally higher amount on essential needs which they cannot reduce (Van Raaij and Verhallen, 1983) as shown on Figure 3 for UK consumers. Secondly, higher-income consumers have a greater ability to invest in measures to reduce their consumption (e.g., double glazing) (Gerarden, Newell and Stavins, 2015). Thirdly, there is information asymmetry between lower-income and higher-income groups, with the former having less access to information and available options (Gerarden, Newell and Stavins, 2015). Lastly, higher-income consumers have a higher energy consumption overall leading to a lower marginal utility for additional units of energy, so reducing consumption when the price increases can be seen as a form of utility maximisation (Nesbakken, 1999).

**2.4 Consumer Surplus**

Consumer surplus is the total amount the consumer is willing to pay minus the cost (QMUL, 2023a). This willingness to pay represents the marginal benefit to a consumer for each unit of consumption. 

 

For a given market demand curve, a change in the price will result in a change in the consumer surplus. As previously shown, due to the different price elasticities for lower-income and higher-income groups, a change in the price will result in a difference in the consumer surplus impact. 

 

 

 

 

**2.5 Deadweight Loss**

(include a bit about what deadweight loss is from Lecture notes) 

 

Deadweight loss can be viewed as a measure of the loss of allocative efficiency that occurs in an economic system that has had a distortion. It is a commonly used measure to potential impacts on welfare (Slesnick, 1991). 

 

Subsidies, such as EPG and EBSS, create a deadweight loss by lowering the price at which a buyer is willing to pay below their associated opportunity cost (Davis, 2014).  

 

The total deadweight loss is a function of the elasticities of demand and supply, where the greater the elasticity of a good the greater the deadweight loss. As such, the difference in the price elasticities between lower-income and higher-income groups will lead to different deadweight losses incurred when a subsidy style policy intervention is put in place. 

**2.6 Market Pricing Structures**

**2.6.1 Uniform Pricing**

**2.6.2 Ramsey Pricing**

**Ramsey pricing developed by Frank Ramsey9 and later Baumol and Bradford (1970)10, is a theory of monopoly pricing, in which monopolies will set prices beyond their marginal cost for a different goods with different elasticities to return more total welfare than under uniform pricing. In this context, Ramsey pricing will be applied to a single good, and will resemble price discrimination for different portions of the market, those with low elasticities receive lower prices and those with higher elasticities receive higher prices, improving social outcomes. However, where price discrimination is undertaken to maximise producer surplus, Ramsey pricing intends to maximise social welfare. The implementation of this price strategy is a second-best solution forced by the revenue requirement and, in this instance, equity considerations in providing progressive form of subsidy. For the purposes of this paper, in increasing producer surplus will be reflected in a lower cost of subsidy to the Government.**

**While typical Ramsey pricing requires multiproduct in separate markets, we can satisfy this requirement by observing the subsidy is applied at an individual level and that the government is able to accurately discern high-income and low-income households and apportion subsidy accurately. Further to this, given energy is very difficult to transfer between consumers, market leakage is unlikely to be an issue.**

**The form of Ramsey pricing applied in this paper is atypical as we are observing the optimal rate of subsidy as opposed to price setting under a profit-making monopoly. Under a subsidy, such as the EPG, there is no marginal cost pricing and therefore no “best-solution”, as the Government is subsidising energy below cost, as such an alternative “second-best” pricing strategy may be the best alternative to increase social welfare. Given the price in this instance is informed by a subsidy, and paid for by the taxpayer, assuming that the tax rate is informed by the rate of the EPG, a higher total cost of EPG will lead to overall decreases in social welfare, therefore a price setting strategy that acknowledges the unequitable nature of a uniform price that can reduce overall cost is imperative to pursue. The Government have a fiscal responsibility to the British public11 and in setting this price they may have wanted to consider the implications of applying a uniform set rate to all consumers.**

**3. Microeconomic Framework**

Essentially want to set up a table of values as example elasticities, define a simple equation for how this changes for income levels (linear?) and have a nice graph with different ones for both short-term and long-term 

 

Potentially compare with [water ](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3486079)to get a rough approximation? 

 

As we have been unable to find literature on how the price elasticity of energy changes by income level, we need to use a proxy to generate indicative price elasticity levels. Water is a similar inelastic good with shared characteristics of some uses being essential and others being discretionary. This paper examines the price elasticity of water in American households concluding the  “result is the steady decrease in the price elasticity of demand as income increases, from -.565 for the low income group to only -.397 for the high income group.” \[[RN10](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3486079)\].  

 

This indicates that lower-income consumers (LIC), in aggregate, have a more elastic price elasticity than higher-income consumers (HIC). This supports our previous rationale that: LIC spends proportionally higher amounts on energy so need to make adjustments when prices change and have less flexibility to invest in energy efficiency or switch to alternative options.
